Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Jackton’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Johanes' Group

texts.en:
Johanes is 33 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Redhi village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Redhi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from the local well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Johanes and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Johanes works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Johanes and 3 other promoters in his community, including Thomas, Hellen, and Prisca need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Johanes will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Johanes wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will enable the community to use safe water with no germs to cause sickness.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Johanes’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Evalyn's Group

texts.en:
Evalyn is 23 years old, has 1 child, and lives in Ramba village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Evalyn works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Where Evalyn lives, her family and her community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Kosawo spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Ramba had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Evalyn is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of her community. Evalyn was elected to represent her community as a volunteer promoter. She is not only representing her community on Kiva, but also volunteers her time to educate the people in Ramba village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at Kosawo spring.There are also 2 other promoters from this community who are also part of this loan: Rose and Peter.

The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Evalyn wants to be a promoter because she  believes that when her community get safe water they will be able to have less water-borne diseases hence improving their health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Evalyn’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Linet's Group

texts.en:
Linet is 30 years old, has 3 children, and lives in Koker B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Linet works as a peasant farmer for a living. Where Linet lives, her family and her community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Kadida spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Koker B had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Linet is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of her community. Linet was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. She is not only representing her community on Kiva, but also volunteers her time to educate the people in Koker B village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. There are also 4 other volunteer promoters in this community: Belinda, Christine, Milicent, and Jared.

The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Linet wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will kill bacteria in water hence making water safe for drinking.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Linet’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah is 32 years old, has 10 children, and lives in Onger B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Sarah works as a business owner for a living. Her community of Onger B village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Sarah is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Sarah represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Sarah and 3 other promoters in her community including Emily, Jane, and Lucy, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Sarah wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will kill germs and make water safe for drinking.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Sarah’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Samwel's Group

texts.en:
Samwel is 29 years old, has 3 children, and lives in Lower Kachwa village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Samwel works as a peasant farmer for a living. His community of Lower Kachwa village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Samwel is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by his village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Samwel represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Samwel and 4 other promoters including Sharon, Nashon, Judith and Seline, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Samwel wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will to help prevent several water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Samwel’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary is 30 years old, has 6 children, and lives in Nyarwenya B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Nyarwenya B village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Kogola spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Mary and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Mary works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Mary and 4 other promoters in her community, including Cynthia, Mathew, Benta and Alice need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Mary will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Mary wants to be a promoter because she  believes that the chlorine will reduce water-borne diseases in the community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Caroline's Group

texts.en:
Caroline is 35 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Obaje West village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Obaje West village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Kowino spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Caroline and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Caroline works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Caroline and other promoters in her community, including Grace, Elizabeth, Benard and George need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Caroline will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Caroline wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will prevent water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Caroline’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Nhóm 5 - Bình Xuyên Group

texts.en: Mrs. Hien, pictured first from the left, is 54 years old. She works as a farmer and makes about 750,000 VND monthly. She does not have a husband, but has 2 grown children. She has been a member of the local Women's Union since 1981. Her family does not have a sanitary toilet. With this loan, she will have a septic tank latrine installed in her home. This will improve the living conditions of the family members, and contribute to the environmental protection.

loans.use: To pay for the construction of a sanitary latrine with a device for hand-washing with soap

loans.name: Nhóm 6 - Bình Xuyên Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Luong, 32, works in the agricultural sector and earns about VND 720,000 monthly. She is married with three little children. She has been a member of the local Women's Union since 2002.

Due to the family's economic hardship, her household does not have a sanitary latrine yet. With this loan, Luong will build a sanitary latrine to improve the living conditions of the family members and contribute to the sanitary improvement in her community.

In this picture, Luong is pictured second from the left.

loans.use: to pay for the construction of a sanitary latrine.

loans.name: Nhóm 7 - Bình Xuyên Group

texts.en: Mrs. Phan, 52, works in agricultural sector and earns a monthly income of approximately 740,000 VND. She has 2 grown children who are currently unemployed, while her husband is usually sick. She has been a member of the local Women's Union since 1984. Her family cannot afford to have a sanitary toilet. Like other members of Group 7 - Binh Xuyen, she will use the fund to build a sanitary latrine to  improve the living conditions for the family members, by preventing diseases commonly associated with unhygienic toilets. She is pictured first from the left in this picture.

loans.use: To pay for the construction of a sanitary latrine with a device for hand-washing with soap

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
Cristita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Cristita has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell in her general store.

Cristita has been in this business for 14 years. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is a 45-year-old married woman with three children, two of whom are currently in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Elena has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fish to sell to her customers.

Elena has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 48 years old, married and has two children who both attend school. He has farmed for 10 years and will use the loan from Kiva to buy fertilizer for maize and beans. The profits from the business will be used to pay for his workers.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for maize and beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sewing material

loans.name: Nino

texts.en:
Nino is a 39-year-old widowed woman, from Kutaisi city. She lives with her parents and her son, who is a student. Nino's parents are temporarily unemployed, and she is the only breadwinner in the family. Nino works at a local financial organization, and is paid a fixed salary. Her income is hardly enough for her family of four to meet all daily costs and monthly expenses. She decided to start a parallel activity, and get additional income for her family's welfare. She requested a loan from local financial institutions to start a business. The start up program, which is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, has enabled her to have her own business. 
With the requested loan of 200 USD, she will purchase jewelry at wholesale prices, and will sell it to her employees and neighbors at increased prices. 
The loan will greatly help her improve her family's living conditions, and give her son a good education which will enable him to progress in life. 
Nino will be very grateful to have a chance to live better.

loans.use: To start selling jewelry to generate additional income

loans.name: Iljos

texts.ru:
Илёс живет в большой и дружной семье, которая всю жизнь занималась животноводством и переработкой молока. Это занятие является основным источником дохода для многих жителей села и пригорода. Илёсу 38 лет.Он вместе со своей семьей живет с пожилыми родителями, помогая им и ухаживая за ними.  Он  женат и имеет двоих детей. Сам  Илёс получил средне-специальное  образование, но в будущем он конечно же хочет чтобы его дети получили  хорошее образование и устроились на хорошую работу.  Поэтому Илёс делает всё, чтобы как можно увеличить доходность от животноводства. Вместе со своей семьей он выращивает скот, продает молоко и произведенные в домашних условиях молочные изделия, шерсть  после стрижки скота.
Дополнительно Илёс  занимается  изготовлением сухофруктов , так как у него есть небольшой сад.Так как  наступили холода и в это время  есть возможность увеличить поголовье скота за счет того что можно приобрести за более выгодную цену он хочет взять кредит и поэтому обратился  в «Арванд». Он несколько раз брал кредиты у нас и доволен обслуживанием и поэтому в этот раз таrже попросил поддержку в нашей организации. Илёс  заранее благодарит  «Арванд» за оказание поддержки.
texts.en:
Iljos lives in a large and close-knit family who have always practiced livestock breeding and milk processing. This business is the main source of income for many village and countryside residents. Iljos is 38 years old. He is married and has two children. Iljos has a secondary-specialized education, but he of course wants his children to receive a good education in the future and find good work. This is why Iljos does all that he can to increase the profitability of his livestock breeding business. Together with his family, he raises cattle, sells milk and makes homemade dairy products and wool from sheering his livestock.

Additionally, Iljos makes dried fruit as he has a small orchard. As the cold has arrived, there is now an opportunity for Iljos increase the size of his herd as he can buy cattle for a more advantageous price. He wants to take out a loan, which is why he turned to "Arvand." He has taken out loans several times from "Arvand" and is pleased with how the whole process was handled. This is why he is asking "Arvand" for a loan again this time around. Iljos thanks "Arvand" in advance for their support.

loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en: Sumaira  is a 26-year-old unmarried woman. She is been in the business of having a beauty parlor for many years. She offers many facilities to her customers such as makeup, hair styling and facials. Through her quality services she has become very famous in her street. In order to meet with the increasing demands of her customers, she is interested in buying greater varieties of cosmetics for the parlor.  That is why she has applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR in order to buy hair care products, skin products and hair rollers in order to service more customers in order to gain profits to build her own house.

loans.use: to buy hair care products, skin products and hair rollers in order to service more customers in order to gain profits to build her own house.

loans.name: Shama

texts.en:
Shama has successfully built her business of a general store with the support of the Kashf Foundation and Kiva. Through time she has attained a good number of customers and makes a good amount of income to contribute to the family income. 

Previously, with the help of Kiva, she was able to expand her business. Now she is in her fifth loan cycle and has applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy stock of grains, oil, spices and cleaning products to meet customers’ demands on time.  She would like to increase earnings in order to provide a better standard of living for family members.

loans.use: to buy stock of grains, oil, spices and cleaning products in order to meet customers’ demands so that she can increase earnings in order to provide a better standard of living for family members.

loans.name: Nhóm 20 - Bình Xuyên Group

texts.en: Mrs. Dung, 43, works in agricultural production, and earns about 750,000 VND monthly. She is married, with 3 grown children who do not live with her. Her husband has been weak and sick for a year. She has been a member of the local Women's Union since 1994. Her family's toilet has been severely damaged, and become unhygienic. With this loan, Dung will build a septic tank latrine to improve the health of her family members and contribute to environmental protection. In this photo, she is pictured first from the left.

loans.use: To pay for the construction of a sanitary latrine with a device for hand-washing with soap

loans.name: Gulzar

texts.en: Gulzar  is 47-years-old and a married woman. The man shown in the photo is Gulzar’s son who is a driver by profession and provides transportation services using his three-wheeled rickshaw. He has been driving a rickshaw for many years in order to meet the family expenses, but now it requires proper maintenance to keep it functional. For this reason, Gulzar  has applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR, for her son. He wants to buy new tires and  spare parts for his vehicle. This will help him drive more smoothly and provide better transport service to his passengers. Gulzar  is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her son and will bring positive changes to his business.

loans.use: to buy new tires and spare parts for her son's vehicle.

loans.name: Nhóm 12 - Bình Xuyên Group

texts.en: Oanh, 27, works as a farmer earning a monthly income of about VND 730,000. She is married with two little children. She has been a member of the local Women's Union since 2007. Her family is classified as a poor family and could not afford to have a sanitary latrine. With this loan, Oanh will use the fund to build a septic tank toilet. This will improve the living conditions for the family members by preventing diseases commonly associated with unhygienic toilets. In this photo, she is pictured first from the right.

loans.use: To pay for the construction of a sanitary latrine with a device for hand-washing with soap

loans.name: Nhóm 13 - Bình Xuyên Group

texts.en: Vien, pictured second from the left, is a 44-year-old farmer who makes about VND 730,000 monthly. She is married with two grown children. She has been a member of the local Women's Union since 1988. Her family does not have a hygienic latrine. A portion of Group 13 - Binh Xuyen's loan will help Vien as well as other group members build a hygienic toilet in her home. This will improve her family's hygiene and health and contribute to the sanitary improvement in her community.

loans.use: To pay for the construction of a sanitary latrine with a device for hand-washing with soap

loans.name: Abdou

texts.fr:
Abdou est un jeune artisan tailleur célibataire qui s’active depuis plus de 5 ans. Il habite un village sérère situé à environ 15km de la ville principale. Abdou a démarré avec son expérience seulement avec l’aide de son père qui lui a remis une petite somme pour l’appuyer. Abdou est tailleur, il confectionne des ensembles sur commande mais aussi pour revendre aux intéressés. Il aura besoin d’une somme pour acheter des variétés de tissus, de fil et le matériel nécessaire pour la confection des habits.
Son produit est bien prisé par la population, c’est pourquoi, il souhaitera avoir un fond plus consistant pour augmenter sa production et satisfaire la clientèle.
texts.en:
Abdou is a young artisan tailor and has been working for more than five years. He is single and lives in a Serer village that is situated about 15 kilometers from the main city. 

Abdou started his work with only his experience and the help of his father who gave him a small sum to support him. He is a tailor and makes outfits by order but also to resell to those who are interested. 

Abdou needs [a loan] to buy a variety of fabrics, string, and the materials necessary to make clothing. 

His products are well received by the population. And this is why he would like to have more consistent funds so that he can expand his production and satisfy his customers.

loans.use: to buy a variety of fabrics, string, and accessories to make outfits

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en: Eufemia is a 59-year-old married woman, and a mother of five grown children, from Concepcion, Iloilo. She has been engaged in a fishing business with her husband for more than 20 years. Eufemia is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets, bamboo, lead weights and other supplies. This loan will enable Eufemia and her husband to improve their fishing business, thus augmenting their income and profit.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets, bamboo, lead weights and other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to cover the  cost of  repairing her husband's rickshaw

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 43 years old and married with three children. With one child currently in school, Elsie works very hard to provide for her family.

Elsie runs a general store in the Philippines and has been in this business for 7 years. She has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries like shampoo, cereals, sanitary pads, diapers, cooking oil, and noodles.

Elsie would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Gloria Emma

texts.es:
Gloria es una madre cabeza de familia de 39 años de edad, tiene dos hijos ambos adolecentes, para ella ha sido muy difícil poder mantener su hogar pero trabajando fuertemente en su venta de alimentos ha generado los ingresos para llevar a su casa. 
Aparte de ser cabeza de familia es una mujer con incapacidad que no le permite emplearse, pero es de admirar verla trabajar no le importa nada solo mantener su hogar, con la ayuda de un crédito quiere impulsar su propia marca para poder distribuirla, comprar una nevera y capital de trabajo para surtido de alimento.
texts.en:
Gloria, aged 39, is a mother and the head of her household. She has two teenage children and has had difficulties upholding her household but by working hard in her food sales she has been able to generate the income to do so.
Although she is the head of the family Gloria has a reduced working capacity and therefore it is admirable to see how she does work to uphold her household. With the help of a loan she hopes to boost her own brand to better distribute it, additionally she wants to buy a refrigerator and acquire working capital to stock up in foodstuffs.

loans.use: to boost her own brand of distributing foodstuffs and to buy inputs for their realization

loans.name: David Giovani

texts.es:
Una incapacidad freno el progreso de David, el tenerse que resignar a dejar trabajos por salud afecto mucho a este hombre que hoy tiene 31 años de edad, pero su espíritu aguerrido y la ayuda de sus familiares lo llevaron a iniciar un negocio de tienda general donde oferta productos de la canasta familiar. 
Comprar vivienda, crear empleo para personas como él se ha vuelto su obsesión y con trabajo y ganas pretende lograrlo.
David solicita un apoyo para la compra de surtido de la canasta familiar en general y quiere que te hagas participe de este lindo proyecto en el cual busca beneficiar a personas como él con oferta de empleo.
texts.en:
A disability holds David back. It greatly affected him when he had to give up jobs for his health. But the now 31-year-old has a fighting spirit and the help of his family enabled him to open a general store where he offers basic foodstuffs. He strives to buy a home and to create employment possibilities for people like him and means to reach this by working hard and staying enthusiastic.
David is asking for a loan to stock his store with foodstuffs in general and hopes you will become part of his project to help people such as himself with an employment offer.

loans.use: to stock up in basic foodstuffs, he is trying to give employment to the disabled

loans.name: Maria Silva

texts.es:
Ella es María una mujer luchadora, aguerrida que le da siempre la cara a los problemas. Un día pro dificultades con su esposo decidió separarse de él quedando a cargo de dos hijos y de un hogar.
Aprovechando sus habilidades culinarias decidió montar en la comodidad de su casa un negocio de venta de alimentos, donde realiza banquetes para eventos, y para vender en la calle, este negocio representa el 100% de sus ingresos y es por este negocio que puede comer y ahora solicita un apoyo par la compra de utensilios que le hacen falta, y de surtido de alimentos pues las deudas la dejaron sin con que invertir y quiere empezar el año de la mejor manera, apóyala, María te necesita.
texts.en:
This is Maria, who is a persevering woman, and she is always brave in the face of problems. She decided to separate from her husband because of difficulties with him, and she continues to care for their two children and a home.

To take advantage of her culinary skills, she decided to start a business selling food from the comfort of her home. She makes feasts for events and food to sell in the street. This business represents 100% of her income, and it is because of this business that she can eat. Now she requests support to buy utensils she lacks and to buy a supply of food, since her debts did not leave her any money that she can invest. She wants to begin the year in the best way. Support her. Maria needs you.

loans.use: to buy utensils and food supplies; since she is a divorced woman, it is very difficult for her to make money, so she needs your support.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy leather.soles, glue, eyelets, and shoelaces for his business
